paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral mRNA vaccination sensitize tumors to immune checkpoint blockade therapy?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 78 tumor‑bearing mice receiving combination of intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti‑PD‑L1 therapy across repeat experiments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 84 tumor‑bearing mice receiving vaccine‑only, ICI‑only, or vehicle control groups.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 130 metastatic cancer patients treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors, assessed by prior SARS‑CoV‑2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 43 patients in the retrospective cohort who had received a SARS‑CoV‑2 mRNA vaccine before ICI therapy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 87 patients in the retrospective cohort without prior mRNA vaccination.

major_limitations: Retrospective human analysis is non‑randomized, risking confounding.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Mouse model findings may not translate directly to all human tumors.
